findings.label: Suppliers with Current Red Flags
findings.detail: 12 current suppliers have Companies House compliance issues (historical payments were made before breaches started)

findings.label: Likely Duplicate Payments
findings.detail: 104 high-confidence duplicate groups with same supplier, amount, date and reference (3+ copies) (after filtering 1113 CSV republication artifacts)
findings.context_note: Quarterly CSV overlaps (same transaction appearing in 2 files) have been filtered out. Remaining duplicates show 3+ identical copies, which are more likely genuine overpayments.

findings.label: Suspected Split Payments
findings.detail: 4 instances of 3+ payments just below approval thresholds in the same week
findings.context_note: Split payment detection has a high false-positive rate. Batch processing, staged invoices, and legitimate recurring payments can all trigger this pattern. FOI request for procurement approval chain recommended before drawing conclusions.

findings.label: Round-Number Payments (>£5K)
findings.detail: 243 exact round-number payments over £5,000 — may indicate estimates rather than invoiced amounts

findings.label: Year-End Spending Pattern
findings.detail: Capital spent 5.2x their monthly average in March (£4.5M above normal). Note: UK councils operate on April–March fiscal years, so elevated March spending is common as departments finalise annual budgets. Spikes above 3x warrant further scrutiny.
findings.context_note: March spending above the monthly average is expected for UK councils on April–March fiscal years. Compare against prior years' March figures for meaningful analysis.

findings.label: Rapid Payment Suppliers
findings.detail: 5 suppliers receive payments every <14 days on average. Top: Moore Switched On Electrical Services (7.0 day avg, 16 payments, £2.2K)

findings.label: Benford's Law Analysis
findings.detail: Digit distribution across 14,266 transactions shows χ²=351.53 (statistically significant due to large sample size), but max digit deviation is only 3.8% — within the normal range for UK council spending patterns. No practical evidence of fabricated invoices.
findings.context_note: Chi-squared values on samples of 14,266+ transactions are naturally inflated and will almost always show statistical significance. The max digit deviation (3.8%) is a more meaningful indicator — deviations under 5% are typical for legitimate council spending.

key_findings.title: 1 suppliers with clock-like payment regularity
key_findings.description: These suppliers receive payments at near-identical intervals (std dev <5 days). Top: S R B C — every 192.0 days (31 payments, £806)

key_findings.title: PATTERSONS (BRISTOL) LTD: 295 transactions totalling £16.3K
key_findings.description: Averaging £55 per transaction — the council's most frequent supplier

key_findings.title: 21 suppliers shared with neighbouring councils — £31.3M total
key_findings.description: Compare what each council pays the same suppliers for similar services

key_findings.title: Liberata UK Ltd: 6494% price gap between councils
key_findings.description: Burnley pays £75.3K avg vs Lancaster £1.1K (both with 3+ transactions). Price differences may reflect different service scope, contract terms, or volumes rather than overcharging — manual review recommended.
key_findings.context_note: Cross-council price comparisons use common financial years only (where both councils have data for the same supplier). This prevents unfair comparisons between councils with different data periods. Differences may still reflect different service levels or contract terms.

suppliers.supplier: DEPARTMENT FOR COMMUNITIES AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT
